title: K-State defense working to slow big plays
text:
K-State defense working to slow big plays By Joel Jellison October 16, 2015 
Kansas State fed the hopes of its fans when it tied TCU at 45 with 1:47 to play last Saturday. 
But in the blink of an eye, those upset dreams turned into sorrows when the Horned Frogs needed just two plays to score the game-winning touchdown on a 55-yard touchdown pass. 
The Horned Frogs gained 210 yards on just three plays in the game, using an 86-yard touchdown run on the first play of the game, a 69-yard run in the fourth quarter and the 55-yard pass near the end of the game to amass a big chunk of their offense. 
TCU needed just 17 plays to gain 454 yards, an average of more than 26 yards per play. 
K-State coach Bill Snyder said the problem with big plays this season has brought back memories of the bend-but-don’t-break defenses of the recent past. 
“We have been prone,” he said. “We went through this two or three years ago. It was about big plays, just giving up large chunks of yardage via the run — (like the) first snap of the ball game — or via long throws. We’ve kind of drifted back that way. We had captured that issue.” 
The Horned Frogs gained just 89 yards on the other 36 plays in the game, averaging less than 2.5 yards per play. 
The Wildcats came into the game holding opponents to 71 rushing yards per game, and allowed the Horned Frogs to rack up 242 yards on the ground. 
K-State has rarely played at full strength on defense this season, and the depth of the secondary was tested more last Saturday than it has been all season. 
Despite the issues with health, Sndyer said it isn’t the major issue of concern on defense, and not an excuse for big plays. 
“It’s easy for me to say we’ve got to stop big plays,” he said. “It’s a matter of being able to say how are we going to do it? That’s what our defensive coaches are working on diligently, all of us are. It’s having a method of being able to correct the mistakes that cause those big plays. That’s probably the biggest hang up that we have right now.” 
Senior linebacker Will Davis said it boils down to better preparation in practice and focus during games. Davis acknowledged big plays have been a killer for the Wildcats, and a contributing factor in blowing halftime leads over the past two weeks. 
Even against Louisiana Tech, a handful of big plays helped the Bulldogs force the Wildcats into overtime at home. 
Davis said the focus this week has been on limiting and eliminating big plays. 
The results of the past few games, however, have lingered in both positive and negative ways. 
“It’s extremely frustrating, but it’s also motivating for a lot of us,” Davis said. “We don’t want to be those guys. We want the game to be on our shoulders and we want to be able to provide that win. 
“It will hurt your mindset, but at the same time a lot of the guys are hungry and motivated.”
